Ex. 8. The Image in this experiment is conveyed to the 
eye by two reflections; the first is from the internal surface 
of the upper glass or lens, & the second from its lower 
internal surface. see fig 1st. Where AB is a plano convex 
lens, & CD a looking glass plate laid ther[e]on, let the light 
come in the direction LPT the Eye at M will see the 
primary set of rings formed round the point of contact 
at P; the rays proceeding from the Image of the primary, 
in passing upwards to the Eye at M, will also in part be 
reflected from its upper internal surface at Q down to R, 
from whence they will again be reflected to the Eye at 
<s>O<\s> N. and these reflections are continued indefinitely. 
So far it was thought necessary to be particular in 
distinguishing these three kinds of <s>prismatic<\s> phenomena 
from each other: not only because reflected Rings 
have not been noticed by Sir Isaac Newton, nor 
even by Dr Herschell except in a cursory manner; 
but because by their means, all the following new 
phenomena have been discovered.<\s>
